name: 1-ethylcyclohexene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.

name: 1-ethylcyclohexene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The base structure here is cyclohexene which has a melting point of approximately -103.9°C. The introduction of an ethyl group generally increases the melting point due to increased van der Waals forces from the larger molecular size. However, in this case, since 1-ethylcyclohexene retains a good deal of conformational flexibility due to its non-polar alkyl chain and the unsaturated bond in the ring, the increase in melting point will not be substantial. Considering the effect of an ethyl group on a six-membered ring containing one double bond, the increase might be expected to be around +6 to +8°C compared to the parent compound.

name: 1-ethylcyclohexene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The base structure, cyclohexene, has a melting point of approximately -103.9°C. An ethyl group would typically contribute to an increase in melting point due to increased van der Waals forces caused by its larger molecular size. In this particular case, the impact is moderated by the flexibility of the molecule introduced by the ethyl group and the presence of the unsaturated bond in the ring, which can prevent efficient packing. The effect of the ethyl group is estimated to raise the melting point by approximately +6 to +8°C.

name: 1-ethylcyclohexene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic reference compound here can be cyclohexane, which has a melting point around 6.5°C. The introduction of a double bond to form cyclohexene generally lowers the melting point because it introduces planarity and rigidity, which disrupts the crystalline packing efficiency, reducing the melting point. This effect might account for a decrease of about 20°C. An ethyl group generally has a smaller effect on the melting point than a longer alkyl chain due to fewer interactions with neighboring molecules, but still increases the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and surface area, leading to better packing and more van der Waals forces. The ethyl group thus might contribute an increase of about 5°C.

name: 1-ethylcyclohexene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic reference compound here could be cyclohexane, which has a melting point of 6.5°C. Introducing a double bond to form cyclohexene typically lowers the melting point due to increased rigidity and planarity that disrupt crystalline packing, which can decrease the melting point by approximately -20°C. The ethyl substituent slightly raises the melting point because it increases molecular weight and surface area, improving van der Waals interactions and packability, potentially causing an increase of about +5°C. However, the reduction due to the double bond is more significant than the increase by the ethyl group, so overall, a net decrease is expected.

name: 1-ethylcyclohexene
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit, cyclohexene, has a melting point of -103.5. An ethyl group is larger than a methyl group and generally increases the melting point due to increased van der Waals forces, but in a cyclic and unsaturated compound, steric hindrance and double bond character can also influence this effect. In the case of cyclohexene derivatives, the introduction of an ethyl group may either raise the melting point slightly due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, or lower it due to steric hindrance disrupting crystal packing. Since 1-ethylcyclohexene has a lower melting point than cyclohexene, it appears that the steric hindrance effect outweighs the increase in molecular weight. The influence of the ethyl group in shifting the melting point could be estimated at around -6.5 degrees celsius when comparing to the base unit of cyclohexene.
